Award.AwardTitle: Signaling interactions between pattern- and effector-triggered immunity in plants
Award.AbstractNarration: Plants have an immune system that is activated when they detect pathogen attack. There are two modes of plant immunity, each triggered by different types of pathogen-derived molecules as cues of attack. How these two modes of immunity influence each other to modify the immune response is not well understood. This project will precisely measure the influence of each mode upon the other and seek to discover the plant proteins that mediate cross-mode interactions. Since the two modes are central in plant immunity, this project will potentially extend our understanding of how plants use their immune system to defend themselves against pathogens. Potential applications of the work include tools and knowledge to improve the performance of the plant immune system in agricultural settings, which can lead to better control of crop diseases with less impact on the environment. Another important aspect of this project is training undergraduate students who have limited time for research work. While this project functions as a pilot case for a new undergraduate training platform, the platform will be easily expanded to involve more students at multiple sites. Therefore, it has the potential to improve biology education for a large number of undergraduate students. Since this project involves statistical and computational components as well as biological components, post-doctoral, doctoral, and undergraduate students will be trained in broad areas of science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plants turn on immune response when they detect pathogen attack. However, microbial pathogens can evolve much faster than plants and have evolved various ways to interfere with the plant immune signaling network, which regulates a battery of plant immune responses. As a counter measure, plants have evolved a very complex network for immune signaling: different parts of the network compensate each other, so that the network can keep functioning even when some parts are disabled by pathogens. To study this complex signaling network, we mainly use the model plant Arabidopsis. In this project, we focused on interactions between two modes of immunity, pattern-triggered and effector-triggered immunity (PTI and ETI), which are triggered by detection of different types of molecular cues from pathogens. Generally, PTI is triggered by very early molecular cues although the information qualities of these early cues are not great (it could be from non-pathogenic microbes): ETI is triggered a little later by much more reliable molecular cues. Another aspect of immune response is that the immune response is bad for plants as well. Therefore, unnecessary immune response should be avoided. One thing we learned in this project is that if PTI signaling is not strongly interfered by pathogens, which suggests that PTI is successful in stopping the pathogens, the later ETI program can be aborted, probably to avoid a bad effect of unnecessary immune responses. This decision of aborting further immune response appears to be made in a conservative manner: multiple different indications of early immune success seem to be needed to make this decision. This is probably because pathogens may quickly evolve to fake such an indicator if only one such indicator is sufficient to make plants to abort the immune program.

It is very difficult to study the mechanisms that are hidden under such a complex network. This is because even when one part of the network is disabled, not much difference is observed in performance of the network because some other parts compensate the loss. Thus, a traditional genetics approach (knocking out one gene at a time) does not give out much information about how the network functions as a whole. To overcome this problem, we simultaneously knocked-out four major components of the network, which largely abolished PTI and ETI. Starting with this broken state of the network, we put back the major components one by one to learn how each component and groups of the components exactly work in the network. Combining this approach (which we call network reconstitution) with measuring the activities of the components through the time after PTI triggered, we built a computer model that explains the signal flow among the network components. Using this PTI model, we learned which particular signal flows are important for the network components to compensate each other and how this network can respond differently to different molecular cues. Using the same strategy but applying it to all the genes whose expression responses are controlled by the immune signaling network, we showed how well the gene expression responses are protected from pathogen attack, and how exactly network component compensations confer this protection effect.

We also studied a molecular platform where PTI and ETI signaling closely interact. We intensively studied a protein complex(es) that contains both a protein that recognizes a molecular cue for PTI triggering and proteins that recognize molecular cues for ETI triggering. This protein complex was centered by the BSK family of protein kinases. While any of the 12 BSKs in Arabidopsis can be part of this complex, we observed different effects of different BSKs on PTI and ETI signaling.

Although the immune signaling network is highly complex, it is important to understand how the network exactly works to rationally guide how we can improve disease resistance in crops. Improvement of crop disease resistance will lead to reduction in use of chemical pesticides, which will contribute to human and environmental health and reduce the cost in agricultural production, and help farmers in developing countries to reduce loss of their crops to disease.

This project also helped undergraduate students to gain research experience. These days many undergraduates are pressed on their time – e.g., many of them need to work to be able to continue their education. On the other hand, a traditional research experience program requires students to commit substantial time. Consequently many biology-major students graduate without research experience. We developed a team research program in which many undergraduate work together for a single project, so that they can accomplish substantial research although each of them spends a manageable amount of time. We believe that giving better education to biology-major students is a great place to start toward improving science literacy among general public.
